task.title: Creating DTDs

titlealts.searchtitle: Creating a new document type definition (DTD)

task.shortdesc: A document type definition (DTD) contains a set of rules that can be used to validate an XML file. After you have created a DTD, you can edit it manually, adding declarations that define elements, attributes, entities, and notations, and how they can be used for any XML files that reference the DTD file.

context.p: The following instructions were written for the Resource perspective, but they will also work in many other perspectives.
Follow these steps to create a new DTD:

step.cmd: If necessary, create a project to contain the DTD.
In the workbench, select File NewOtherXML DTD and click Next.
Select the project or folder that will contain the DTD.
In the File name field, type the name of the DTD, for example MyDTD.dtd.
step.info: The name of your DTD file must end with the extension .dtd

step.cmd: You can use a DTD template as the basis for your new DTD file. To do so, click the Use DTD Template check box, and select the template you want to use.

result.p: The DTD appears in the Navigator view and automatically, by default, opens in the DTD editor. In the DTD editor, you can manually add elements, attributes, notations, entities, and comments to the DTD. If you close the file, and want to later re-open it in the DTD editor, double-click it in the Navigator view.
